ReviewList.Text: Full disclosure: I got the book on special for free, and I still feel like I was ripped off.  The writing is TERRIBLE, the plot is weak, and unless you're 13 years old, high, or both, you cannot possibly suspend reality enough for anything that happens in the book to make sense.  You'll also catch yourself constantly asking,  "What is happening here? Why is [name. any. character.] reacting like this? It makes no sense."  The book is clearly trying to be something like the Hunger Games (but oooh; with mind reading!) and it falls incredibly short.  You can understand why Katniss would be angry, but the heroine of this tale (with her seriously forgettable name) basically alternates between three states of mental being and none of them are even remotely realistic or interesting.  I can't stress this enough: even if you can read it for free, do NOT waste your time.  Don't.

This is one young adult book that does not transcend to adult reading. To quote CS Lewis, “No book is really worth reading at the age of ten which is not equally – and often far more – worth reading at the age of fifty and beyond.”

Not horrible, but not great either. The lead character is shallow and superficial with no real depth, and so are all of the people she interacts with with in her age range (young adult - adult). The most interesting characters are the peripheral characters, like the Janitor and the little kids, who don't hold a large part.

Susan Kaye Quinn introduces us to a fascinating world of mind-readers and mind "jackers." Her descriptions of what that kind of world would feel like (and smell like) are delicious. I started reading Open Minds and couldn't put it down. The heroine was believable and relatable and had a solid story goal and story arc. I immediately ordered and read Book Two and passed them onto my college-aged daughter. We both eagerly await the third book in the trilogy.
characters under developed. Simon is far from likeable and seems like he could easily be a rapist/ molester. kind of disgusted by the main characters choice to allow the relationship.

My main problem with this book was Simon. He's abusive and there are numerous warning signs that Kira points out yet she continues to be with him and listen to him. It's not even out of fear. She has opportunities to leave him and doesn't. Other than Simon the book was pretty good. I didnt like the constant use of words like "demens" because they have no meaning in our society and was used in so many different situations that it was difficult to tell exactly what it meant. I think it's some form of crazy. I did like the amount of action and once Simon was out of the picture I enjoyed it more but that took at least half the book.

If I start a book, I have to finish it.  But I found myself watching the percentage read more than the words on the page throughout most of this novel.  A really slow plot about a mind-reading population with unclear powers and ever-changing abilities was almost enough to make me break my personal rule and quit reading several times.  The book finally picked up in action a bit, but not until almost the end.  Lackluster characters, absent descriptions of anything, and a fuzzy purpose all contributed to a great big snore of a novel that just didn't seem finished.  I'm truly happy that nobody can "jack" into my brain and make me read the second book!

I'm not usually into supernatural tales.  This one is so well written that I soon started accepting telepathy as the way things are.  Characters one can identify with, and a well developed plot.  Clear line between the good and the bad guys, I like that.  A book I would put in the hands of a young reader, and would recommend to adult readers as light entertainment as well.

The first half was very long winded. I paged through a fourth of the book to find Kira in the exact same situation she'd already been in. The second half is better put together, faster paced, and a lot more interesting.

The heroine was frustrating. I understand the need for some uncertainty given that she was young but I felt I was never given a chance to like her. She was just so indecisive and contradictory about absolutely everything that it was hard to get past that and enjoy an otherwise well written book.

I try to give an honest review for every kindle book I buy.  Mostly because I want the readers to have a good idea on what to expect.  I might have given it 3 1/2 if that was an option.  The premise was really cool.  Difficult to write about, I believe, but the author did a pretty good job of conveying how the mind reading worked.  I did not really feel much about the characters however. They were ok, just did not affect me emotionally. Some details were a little lax.  I did read it pretty fast because of the cool subject material and I most likely will buy the next installment.  So take it for what it's worth.  Good but not great.
